questions.text: There are many factors that influence sodium reabsorption and excretion in the kidneys. Which of the following causes increased excretion of sodium into the urine?
questions.solution:
Sodium is a major component of the extracellular fluid and accounts for a major part of blood osmolality. Sodium homeostasis is the process of regulating the amount of sodium in the extracellular fluid and is mainly achieved by the kidneys.

The two major factors that affect sodium homeostasis are blood volume and pressure.

In the setting of a drop in blood volume and pressure (e.g. hemorrhage), mechanisms are activated to increase sodium and water reabsorption from the kidneys to restore blood volume and pressure. One such system is the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone-system (RAAS). Renin converts angiotensinogen to angiotensin, and angiotensin II increases sodium reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubules. Additionally, angiotensin II stimulates the release of aldosterone, which acts on the collecting ducts and tubules to increase sodium reabsorption. Moreover, sympathetic activation increases the reabsorption of sodium both indirectly (through stimulation of renin release) and directly by acting on the proximal convoluted tubules to increase sodium reabsorption. Finally, antidiuretic hormone (ADH) released from the posterior pituitary in response to low blood volume increases sodium reabsorption in the thick limb of the loop of Henle.

In contrast, increased blood pressure and volume stimulates sodium excretion (and eventually water) in the kidneys. This effect is achieved not only through the aforementioned mechanisms but also by certain hormones such as atrial natriuretic peptide, which is secreted by the atria in response to increased blood volume.

Other factors that also influence sodium homeostasis include serum osmolarity, wherein increased osmolarity of blood causes increased sodium excretion and vice versa.   

Option Analysis

✅ Increased circulating blood volume:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sympathetic activation:
Incorrect: Sympathetic activation decreases the excretion of sodium into the urine and increases sodium reabsorption. These effects are achieved indirectly (through increasing renin release) and directly through increasing sodium reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubules.  
❌ Decreased blood pressure:
Incorrect: Decreased blood pressure causes activation of the sympathetic system and renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, both of which increase sodium reabsorption.  
❌ Decreased serum osmolarity:
Incorrect: Decreased serum osmolarity causes increased reabsorption of sodium in the kidneys.  
❌ Decreased parathyroid hormone levels:
Incorrect: Parathyroid hormone inhibits the sodium-phosphate transporter in the proximal convoluted tubules, thus increasing the amount of sodium excreted in the urine. Therefore, decreased parathyroid hormone levels cause decreased excretion of sodium into the urine.

questions.text: A group of researchers are studying the physiology of the loop of Henle. They discover that the loop of Henle plays an important role in concentrating urine by generating a hypertonic medullary interstitium in a process called countercurrent multiplication. Which of the following is true regarding the loop of Henle?

choices.text: The thick ascending loop of Henle is impermeable to sodium
The Na-K-2Cl channel is located on the apical surface of the thick ascending loop of Henle
The thin descending loop makes urine less concentrated as it descends
The Na+/Ca2+ exchanger on the thin limb increases the calcium reabsorption
65-80% of filtered sodium is reabsorbed in the loop of Henle

questions.solution:
The loop of Henle consists of three major segments based on cellular morphology and anatomic location.
 
  • Descending thin limb: Lined by squamous epithelial cells containing aquaporin proteins on the apical and basolateral surfaces and very few channels for solutes. The osmolarity in the medullary interstitium increases from 300 mOsm/L to 1200 mOsm/L at the end of descending limb, mostly due to the sodium gradient. 
  • Ascending thin limb: Sodium and chloride channels lie on the apical and basolateral surfaces. The interstitial fluid osmolarity decreases to around 600 mOsm/L at the top of the thin ascending loop. 
  • Ascending thick limb: Lined by cuboidal cells, which do not have aquaporin proteins and are impermeable to water. The apical surfaces have Na+K+2Cl- cotransporters that shuttle one sodium into the cell down its concentration gradient, which powers the movement of one potassium and two chlorides into the cell. On the basolateral surface, a Na/K ATPase uses ATP, which indirectly induces paracellular reabsorption of magnesium and calcium. 
Further up the thick ascending loop, the tubular fluid starts decreasing in osmolarity due to solute removal, reaching around 325 mOsm/L at the top of the thick ascending loop. The process of creating this gradient is called countercurrent multiplication. During this process, ATP is used to augment the concentration gradient and in return reabsorb water.    


Option Analysis

❌ The thick ascending loop of Henle is impermeable to sodium:
Incorrect: The thick ascending loop of Henle is impermeable to water. The thin descending loop of Henle is impermeable to sodium.  
✅ The Na-K-2Cl channel is located on the apical surface of the thick ascending loop of Henle:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The thin descending loop makes urine less concentrated as it descends:
Incorrect: The thick ascending loop makes urine less concentrated as it ascends, as it causes reabsorption of solutes down the concentration gradient and is impermeable to water.  
❌ The Na+/Ca2+ exchanger on the thin limb increases the calcium reabsorption:
Incorrect: The Na/Ca exchanger is located on the distal convoluted tubule. Calcium reabsorbs paracellularly in the thick ascending limb.  
❌ 65-80% of filtered sodium is reabsorbed in the loop of Henle:
Incorrect: Only 10-20% of the filtered sodium is reabsorbed in the thick ascending limb.

questions.text: A group of researchers is examining the relative concentrations of several substances along the proximal convoluted tubule. They discover one substance that can be used to approximate renal plasma flow. This substance is denoted by which of the following lines detailed in the graph below?
questions.solution:
The substance in question is reflective of para-aminohippuric acid (PAH), which can be used to approximate renal plasma flow (RPF). This molecule is wholly removed from the blood that passes through the kidneys. It undergoes glomerular filtration and tubular secretion due to unique transport molecules on the basolateral membrane of the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT). The only case in which this does not occur is when these transport molecules are fully saturated, leaving some PAH in the bloodstream. In the former case, when PAH filtration falls below its maximum transport, all the PAH making it to the kidneys is removed from the blood that passes through them. Thus, RPF can be calculated using PAH as a surrogate marker by taking the concentration of PAH in the urine (UPAH) times the urine flow rate (V), all divided by the concentration of PAH in the renal artery (PPAH).  

 


This is in contrast to inulin (depicted by line B), which is neither secreted nor reabsorbed in the proximal tubule resulting in a lower relative concentration than PAH. It increases in concentration along the proximal convoluted tubule due to water reabsorption.  

Option Analysis

✅ A:
Correct: See Main Explanation   
❌ B:
Incorrect: This line depicts inulin concentration along the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT). Its clearance rate approximates the glomerular filtration rate (GFR).   
❌ C:
Incorrect: This line depicts glucose concentration along the PCT. It falls as glucose is reabsorbed more quickly than water, making its tubular fluid/plasma (TF/Px) concentration <1.   
❌ D:
Incorrect: This line depicts sodium concentration along the PCT, which reflects a TF/Px concentration of approximately 1, showing that sodium and water are reabsorbed at almost the same rate.   
❌ E:
Incorrect: This line depicts chloride. Reabsorption of this molecule occurs slower than water in early proximal convoluted tubules and then matches the rate of water reabsorption more distally.

questions.text: A group of researchers is examining the relative concentrations of several substances along the proximal convoluted tubule. They discover one substance that is ideal for estimating the glomerular filtration rate. This substance is denoted by which of the following lines detailed in the graph below?
questions.solution:
The substance in question is most likely inulin, which can be used to approximate the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Inulin is a naturally occurring polysaccharide molecule that is biologically inert, unbound by plasma proteins, freely filtered at the glomerulus, and is neither reabsorbed, nor secreted by the kidneys. It increases in concentration along the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) due to water reabsorption.  

In contrast, Para-aminohippuric acid (PAH) (Line A) can be used to approximate renal plasma flow (RPF). It is both filtered and secreted in the PCT and is not reabsorbed. As a result, it is wholly removed from the blood that passes through the kidneys. It undergoes glomerular filtration and tubular secretion due to unique transport molecules on the basolateral membrane of the PCT.  

Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: Line A reflects para-aminohippuric acid (PAH), which can be used to approximate renal plasma flow (RPF), not the glomerular filtration rate.  
✅ B:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ C:
Incorrect: This line depicts glucose concentration along the PCT. It falls as glucose is reabsorbed more quickly than water, making its tubular fluid/plasma (TF/Px) concentration <1.  
❌ D  :
Incorrect: This line depicts sodium concentration along the PCT, which reflects a TF/Px concentration of approximately 1, showing that sodium and water are reabsorbed at almost the same rate.  
❌ E:
Incorrect: This line depicts chloride. Reabsorption of this molecule occurs slower than water in early proximal convoluted tubules and then matches the rate of water reabsorption more distally.

questions.text: A graduate student is using mice models to study kidney physiology. A sample of chemical X, a mineralocorticoid that is produced in the zona glomerulosa of the human adrenal gland, is successfully obtained. Afterward, chemical X is injected into the mice models and its effects are recorded. Assuming mice and human kidneys have similar physiology, which of the following best describes the effect that chemical X would have on serum electrolyte levels?
questions.solution:
Aldosterone is a mineralocorticoid hormone produced in the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex. It exerts a downstream effect on α-intercalated cells and principal cells of the cortical collecting duct.

The principal cell has two pumps on its apical surface. First, it has epithelial sodium channels (ENaCs) that bring sodium into the cell. Second, it has potassium channels that excrete potassium into the renal tubule.

The α-intercalated cell mainly excretes hydrogen into the urine and utilizes two pumps on its apical surface. First, it has an H+-ATPase, which pumps hydrogen into the tubule. Second, it has an H+/K+-ATPase, which pushes one hydrogen into the tubule in exchange for one potassium.

The activity of these cells is regulated by aldosterone. In principal cells, aldosterone diffuses across the basolateral membrane and binds to cytoplasmic mineralocorticoid receptors. The aldosterone-receptor complex then enters the nucleus, triggering the increased synthesis of ENaCs and potassium channels. Together, they increase sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion into the urine. In α-intercalated cells, aldosterone increases the synthesis of H+-ATPase and H+/K+-ATPase, resulting in increased hydrogen secretion into the urine.

The net effect of aldosterone is increased serum sodium levels and decreased serum potassium and hydrogen levels.
 

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: Aldosterone is produced in the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal gland. It acts on principal and α-intercalated cells of the collecting tubule. In principal cells, aldosterone increases sodium reuptake and potassium excretion into the urine. The latter would cause serum potassium levels to decline.   
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Aldosterone acts on principal cells, causing increased sodium reuptake from the urine and increased potassium excretion into the urine. In addition, aldosterone acts on the α-intercalated cells, where it increases hydrogen excretion. Thus, aldosterone would cause an increase in serum sodium but a decrease in serum potassium and hydrogen.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Aldosterone is produced in the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal gland. It acts on principal cells in the collecting duct of the nephron, increasing sodium reuptake and potassium excretion into the urine. As a result, administration of aldosterone to mice models would cause an increase in serum sodium and a decline in serum potassium.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Aldosterone acts on principal cells in the collecting duct of the nephron, causing increased sodium reuptake and increased potassium excretion into the urine. Injection of aldosterone into the mice model would cause an increase in serum sodium and a decrease in serum potassium.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office for a follow-up of hypertension. The patient has had elevated blood pressure measurements on several occasions. The patient feels well and does not report any symptoms. Past medical history is unremarkable. Family history is significant for coronary artery disease in the patient’s father. He does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drugs. Temperature is 36.8 C (98.2 F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 150/98 mmHg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient is started on a drug that acts on the segment of the nephron labeled “A” below. Which of the following best describes the normal function of this segment of nephron?

choices.text: Major site for sodium chloride and sodium bicarbonate reabsorption
Pumps sodium, potassium, and chloride out of the lumen into the interstitium of the kidney
Reabsorbs calcium under the control of parathyroid hormone
Primary site of acidification of the urine and is controlled by aldosterone
Passively reabsorbs H2O via medullary hypertonicity and is impermeable to sodium

questions.solution:
The segment of the nephron labeled A is the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). It is affected by thiazide diuretics (e.g. hydrochlorothiazide). This segment of the nephron reabsorbs sodium and chloride via the Na+/Cl– carrier on the apical surface of the tubule and is responsible for 5% of filtered sodium reabsorption. The cotransporter moves Na+ in the direction of its concentration gradient and uses that energy to move a chloride against its concentration gradient. Once inside, chloride leaves via Cl- channels on the basolateral surface into the interstitium, down its concentration gradient. It is impermeable to H2O and makes urine fully dilute (hypotonic).

There are also Ca++ channels on the apical surface and Na+/Ca++ channels on the basolateral surface of the tubule cells. Ca++ ions can diffuse across the apical surface into the tubule cells, down their concentration gradient, and then move across the basolateral surface into the interstitium against their concentration gradient as 1 Na+ moves from the interstitium into the tubule cells. Calcium reabsorption is regulated by the parathyroid hormone (PTH). Moreover, the Na+/K+ ATPase on the basolateral surface keeps the intracellular Na+ level low, and that allows more Na+ to flow into the tubule, down its concentration gradient on the basolateral surface through the Na+/Ca++ channels, and on the apical surface through the Na+/Cl- cotransporter.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Major site for sodium chloride and sodium bicarbonate reabsorption :
Incorrect: The proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) carries out isosmotic reabsorption of amino acids, glucose, and numerous ions. It is the major site for sodium chloride and sodium bicarbonate reabsorption. The proximal tubule is responsible for 60–70% of the total reabsorption of sodium. The segment marked A is the distal convoluted tubule. 
❌ Pumps sodium, potassium, and chloride out of the lumen into the interstitium of the kidney :
Incorrect: The thick ascending loop of Henle has a Na-K-2Cl symporter which pumps sodium, potassium, and chloride out of the lumen into the interstitium of the kidney. The segment marked A is the distal convoluted tubule. 
✅ Reabsorbs calcium under the control of parathyroid hormone :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Primary site of acidification of the urine and is controlled by aldosterone :
Incorrect: The collecting duct is the final segment of the nephron and is the last tubular site of sodium reabsorption that is controlled by aldosterone. It is also the primary site of acidification of the urine and the last site of potassium excretion. The segment marked A is the distal convoluted tubule. 
❌ Passively reabsorbs H2O via medullary hypertonicity and is impermeable to sodium :
Incorrect: The descending limb of loop of Henle passively reabsorbs H2O via medullary hypertonicity and is impermeable to sodium. The segment marked A is the distal convoluted tubule.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is being evaluated in the office for persistent failure to thrive. The patient has not achieved normal developmental milestones. After a complete evaluation, the physician suspects Bartter syndrome, which is a renal disorder caused by defective Cl- reabsorption by the Na+/K+/2Cl- cotransporter.  In healthy individuals, the segment of the nephron that houses this transporter is also characterized by which of the following?

choices.text: Most concentrated segment of the nephron

questions.solution:
The Na+/K+/2Cl- cotransporters are located in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, which is impermeable to water.       

Epithelial cells along the thick ascending limb have Na+/K+/2Cl- cotransporters on the apical surface, which actively reabsorb sodium down its concentration gradient. This movement of sodium powers the movement of one potassium and two chlorides into the cell as well. These changes also cause paracellular reabsorption of Ca2+ and Mg2+ (secondary to the positive lumen potential established by K+ backleak).        

On the basolateral surface of the tubule cell, a Na+/K+ ATPase uses ATP to pump three sodium ions into the interstitial fluid in exchange for letting two potassium ions into the cell. The Na+/K+ ATPase pump helps maintain the low sodium concentration inside the cell. Finally, both chloride and potassium move passively through their own channels down their concentration gradient from the cell into the interstitial fluid as well.       

The thick ascending loop of Henle is impermeable to water, and thus, is known as the diluting segment. This segment is responsible for approximately 10-20% of the Na+ reabsorbed from the nephron.   



Option Analysis

❌ Most concentrated segment of the nephron:
Incorrect: The descending limb of the loop of Henle is permeable to water but not to solutes. Water moves down its concentration gradient in this segment of the nephron from the lumen to the highly osmotic medulla. Tubular fluid will be most concentrated at the bottom of the loop of Henle. 
✅  Impermeability to water:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Site of action of ADH:
Incorrect: Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) binds to V2 receptors on the collecting tubules, thereby increasing their permeability to water. In contrast, the Na+/K+/2Cl- cotransporters are located in the ascending loop of Henle. 
❌  Isotonic tubular fluid:
Incorrect: The tubular fluid in the proximal convoluted tubule remains isotonic as the water is reabsorbed along with the electrolytes. In contrast, the Na+/K+/2Cl- cotransporters are located in the ascending loop of Henle. 
❌ Controlled by aldosterone:
Incorrect: The collecting duct is the final segment of the nephron. Sodium reabsorption at this site is controlled by aldosterone. In contrast, the Na+/K+/2Cl- cotransporters are located in the ascending loop of Henle.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman comes to the office for the evaluation of recurrent episodes of urinary tract infection. She has had five episodes of cystitis and an episode of pyelonephritis over the last year. The rest of the history is unremarkable, and she does not have any other medical conditions. Family history is noncontributory. She has not been sexually active for the last six months. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 17/min and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows mild suprapubic tenderness. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is shown below. Which of the following structures is involved in the pathophysiology of this patient’s findings on the CT scan?  


Reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient’s CT scan shows both renal lower poles pointing medially and seen fused across the midline by an isthmus of functioning renal tissue. This abnormality is known as horseshoe kidney and affects about 1 in 500 people.  

Normally, the kidneys rest in the retroperitoneum between the T12 and L3 vertebrae after ascending from the pelvis. In some patients, the kidneys are fused mechanically at the poles where the central isthmus of the horseshoe kidney lies anterior to the aorta and posterior to the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA). During fetal development, its ascent is arrested by the IMA.    

Most patients are asymptomatic, and for these patients, the horseshoe kidney is diagnosed incidentally. It, however, increases the risk of ureteropelvic junction obstruction, recurrent infections, urolithiasis, and renal tumors.  



Option Analysis

❌ Superior mesenteric artery:
Incorrect: The superior mesenteric artery arises from the anterior surface of the abdominal aorta between the celiac trunk superiorly and inferior mesenteric artery inferiorly at the level of L1 vertebrae and does not serve as an obstacle for the ascend of the kidney.  
✅ Inferior mesenteric artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inferior vena cava:
Incorrect: The inferior vena cava is a large vein formed by the joining of the right and the left common iliac veins, usually at the level of the fifth lumbar vertebra. It does not prevent the normal ascent of the kidneys.
❌ Third part of the duodenum:
Incorrect: The third part of the duodenum begins at the inferior duodenal flexure and passes transversely to the left, passing in front of the inferior vena cava, abdominal aorta, and the vertebral column. The superior mesenteric artery and vein are anterior to the third part of the duodenum.  
❌ Urachal fistula:
Incorrect: A urachal fistula is a congenital disorder caused by the persistence of the allantois (later, urachus), the structure that connects an embryo's bladder to the yolk sac. It is usually diagnosed earlier in life.

questions.text: A 2-hour-old newborn boy is evaluated in the nursery for breathing difficulty. He was born at term to a 22-year-old primigravida mother who received no prenatal care. He is at the 35th percentile for length and below the 10th for weight. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 160/min, respirations are 60/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg. On physical examination, the infant appears in distress. Subcostal retractions and nasal flaring are present. Low-set ears, retrognathia, flattened nose, and bilateral feet deformities are noted. Abdominal examination reveals bilaterally enlarged masses. Which of the following additional findings would most likely be discovered upon further evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
This newborn infant has Potter sequence, which is characterized by limb deformities, facial anomalies, and pulmonary hypoplasia. Potter sequence is caused by low amniotic fluid volume, which leads to compression of the fetus and abnormal development. Although Potter sequence is associated with many conditions, the presence of bilateral abdominal masses suggests that autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) is the underlying cause.  

ARPKD, as the name implies, is an autosomal recessive genetic condition characterized by cystic dilation of the collecting ducts. It is also associated with biliary dysgenesis and hepatic fibrosis. The condition is caused by mutations in the PKHD1 gene located on chromosome 6p21, which encodes for a membrane protein called fibrocystin (or polyductin). Fibrocystin’s function is unknown, but it can be found throughout the kidneys and hepatic ducts.  

The clinical presentation of ARPKD varies and is based on the age of onset as well as extent of hepatic and/or renal involvement. Patients may present with Potter sequence, bilateral flank masses, hypertension, progressive renal insufficiency, and portal hypertension due to congenital hepatic fibrosis. Note that in contrast to ARPKD, autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease manifests in adulthood.  

Option Analysis

❌ Saccular aneurysm:
Incorrect: Berry aneurysms are associated with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). ADPKD typically presents in adulthood with flank pain, hematuria, hypertension, urinary tract infections, and progressive renal failure. The condition is also associated with mitral valve prolapse, benign hepatic cysts, and diverticulosis. This patient's early presentation favors another diagnosis.    
❌ Aniridia :
Incorrect: Aniridia is associated with the WAGR complex, a genetic condition that presents with Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma), aniridia (absence of the iris), genitourinary malformations, and intellectual disability. It arises due to mutations in the WT1 or WT2 genes. Wilms tumor presents as a unilateral smooth mass that does not typically cross the midline. In contrast, this patient has bilateral abdominal masses.  
❌ Duodenal atresia:
Incorrect: Duodenal atresia is associated with Down syndrome (trisomy 21). Down syndrome would not present with the bilateral foot deformities, hypertension, and bilateral abdominal masses described in this vignette.  
✅ Hepatic fibrosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Horseshoe kidney:
Incorrect: Horseshoe kidney is an anomaly wherein the kidneys are fused in the inferior pole and trapped under the inferior mesenteric artery. Most often, patients are asymptomatic and have normal kidney function. Some patients may develop hydronephrosis, renal stones, and infections. The condition is associated with chromosomal aneuploidy syndromes (e.g., Turner syndrome, trisomies 13, 18, 21). However, the constellation of findings in this patients is more consistent with autosomal recessive polycystic disease.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old female comes to the primary care physician for a follow-up appointment. The patient is currently asymptomatic and denies increased urinary frequency or dysuria. However, she has had multiple urinary tract infections during the past year, each of which resolved with antibiotic therapy. Additionally, the patient has had 3 episodes of calcium oxalate nephrolithiasis treated with conservative measures. She is sexually active, in a monogamous relationship, and uses condoms consistently. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Urinalysis and IV pyelography are obtained and the results are shown below:  
 
 Urine  
 Color  Yellow 
 Clarity  Clear 
 Erythrocytes  8/hpf 
 Leukocytes  2/hpf 
 pH   5.5 
 Nitrates  Negative 
 Glucose   Negative 
 Protein  Negative 
 Bacteria   None 
 Sediment   None 


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has recurrent episodes of nephrolithiasis and urinary tract infections, raising suspicion for an underlying condition. The urinalysis is positive for blood, negative for leukocytosis, and has a normal pH, suggesting there is no current infection. The pyelography shows bilateral dilated tubules, which is consistent with medullary sponge kidney.  

Medullary sponge kidney is a congenital disorder characterized by abnormal development of the terminal collecting ducts as well as formation of diffuse medullary cysts of varying sizes. In contrast, the renal cortex is spared. The underlying pathophysiology is not fully understood.  

The majority of patients with medullary sponge kidney disease are asymptomatic and diagnosed incidentally on imaging done for another cause. Some patients may present with urinary tract infections and nephrolithiasis, as seen here. Rarely, it can lead to chronic kidney disease and renal failure.  

Diagnosis is typically made with IV pyelogram, which will show dilated renal tubules and, in some cases, nephrocalcinosis or nephrolithiasis. Prognosis is usually excellent, and plasma creatinine concentration remains normal in the majority of cases. However, recurrent urinary infections and stones increase the risk of acute kidney injury. Treatment is aimed to resolve the symptoms of infections and nephrolithiasis.  




Option Analysis

❌ Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease:
Incorrect: Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease is a genetic condition typified by cystic dilation of the collecting ducts as well as biliary dysgenesis and hepatic fibrosis. Patients often present at birth with Potter sequence, bilateral flank masses, hypertension, progressive renal insufficiency, and portal hypertension. This patient’s age and presentation favors another diagnosis. 
❌ Infection by urease forming bacteria:
Incorrect: Infection by urease forming bacteria, such as Proteus mirabilis, can lead to the formation of magnesium ammonium phosphate (struvite) stones. Struvite stones are large and often referred to as staghorn calculi. Although the radiographic image resembles a struvite stone, the absence of urinary symptoms (e.g., dysuria, colicky flank pain) and normal urinary pH (struvite stones typically precipitate in alkaline pH) favor another diagnosis. 
❌ Vesicoureteral reflux:
Incorrect: Vesicoureteral reflux is the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder into the ureters due to inadequate closure of the ureterovesical junction. Patients often develop hydronephrosis or recurrent urinary tract infection early in life. Diagnosis is made with a contrast voiding cystourethrogram, as opposed to IV pyelogram.
✅ Medullary sponge kidney:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Chronic pyelonephritis:
Incorrect: Chronic pyelonephritis is caused by long-lasting pyogenic infections of the kidney. It occurs almost exclusively in patients with an underlying anatomic abnormality (e.g. vesicoureteral reflux). Symptoms are vague but patients may endorse fever, flank or abdominal pain, malaise, and anorexia. Urinalysis typically shows epithelial cells, granular casts, and occasionally WBC casts. Imaging would reveal focal scarring of the renal cortex and distortion of the renal calyces.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida woman at 20 weeks of gestation comes to the obstetrician for a routine prenatal evaluation. The pregnancy has been uncomplicated, and she has been compliant with prenatal care. She takes vitamins as needed. Family and medical history are unremarkable. She did not have any prior abortions or miscarriages. Ultrasound reveals numerous cysts and no identifiable renal tissue at the location of the fetus’s right kidney. The fetus’s left kidney appears normal. Amniotic fluid index is normal. These ultrasound findings are most likely caused by which of the following?

choices.text: Congenital failure of the metanephric mesenchyme to differentiate
Congenital failure of the ureteric bud to develop
Congenital bifurcation of the ureteric bud

questions.solution:
Fetal ultrasound shows a normal amniotic fluid index, a cystic mass with absent renal tissue, and a normal left kidney, which favors the diagnosis of multicystic dysplastic kidney.   

Multicystic dysplastic kidney is the most severe form of cystic renal dysplasia. The dysplastic kidney is composed of numerous cysts intertwined with dysplastic tissue without identifiable renal tissue. The ureter may be absent or atretic. The exact pathogenesis is not entirely clear. However, it is thought to be due to failure of the ureteric bud to induce differentiation of the metanephric blastema during embryogenesis.  

The condition is predominantly non-hereditary and unilateral. If bilateral involvement occurs, Potter sequence ensues. The majority of cases do not require intervention, since the contralateral kidney is able to compensate. Observation and long-term follow-up are required to monitor for other comorbidities that may affect the healthy kidney (e.g., vesicoureteral reflux, ureteropelvic junction obstruction).    

Option Analysis

❌ Autosomal dominant hereditary condition:
Incorrect: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is caused by a mutation in the PKD1 gene on chromosome 16 or PKD2 gene on chromosome 4. Patients typically present in adulthood with hypertension, hematuria, proteinuria, and impaired kidney function, as well as bilateral flank masses on imaging or physical examination. This fetus has only one nonfunctional kidney, which makes ADPKD very unlikely.   
❌ Autosomal recessive hereditary condition:
Incorrect: Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) is a genetic condition characterized by cystic dilation of the collecting ducts, biliary dysgenesis, and hepatic fibrosis. Patients often present at birth with Potter sequence, bilateral flank masses, hypertension, progressive renal insufficiency, and portal hypertension. This fetus has only one nonfunctional kidney, which makes ARPKD very unlikely.   
✅ Congenital failure of the metanephric mesenchyme to differentiate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Congenital failure of the ureteric bud to develop:
Incorrect: Failure of the ureteric bud to develop during would cause unilateral renal agenesis. Individuals with renal agenesis would not have a kidney or ureter on the affected side. The fetal ultrasound shows cystic nonfunctional tissue, which favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Congenital bifurcation of the ureteric bud:
Incorrect: Congenital bifurcation of the ureteric bud during embryonic development would cause a duplex collecting system, resulting in 2 separate collecting systems. Patients with duplex collecting systems can be asymptomatic or present with urinary tract infections, hydronephrosis, and vesicoureteral reflux. However, fetal ultrasound shows cystic nonfunctional tissue, which favors an alternative diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a follow-up appointment after hospitalization for pyelonephritis. The patient has had multiple episodes of urinary tract infections over the past few years. She is otherwise healthy. She does not use tobacco, alcohol or illicit substances. Family history is unremarkable. The patient’s physical exam is normal. A CT of the abdomen obtained during hospitalization is shown below:  


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following best explains these findings?

choices.text: Failure of neural crest cell migration

questions.solution:
This patient has recurrent urinary tract infections, which raises suspicion for an underlying cause. The abdominal CT reveals the presence of a horseshoe kidney. Horseshoe kidney is the most common fusion anomaly and usually occurs due to fusion of the lower poles of the kidneys.  

Normally, during fetal development, the future kidneys develop in the pelvis as a structure called the metanephros and subsequently migrate upward to their normal position in the retroperitoneal renal fossa. In horseshoe kidney, however, the fused kidneys are lodged under the inferior mesenteric artery. This prevents their ascent into the abdomen and results in ectopy.  

Most patients are asymptomatic and are diagnosed incidentally, but some may present with pain and hematuria due to obstruction or infection. Horseshoe kidney is associated with hydronephrosis, vesicoureteral reflux, renal stones, infection, and chromosomal aneuploidy syndromes (e.g., Turner syndrome, trisomies 13, 18, 21). In addition, the condition increases the risk of kidney cancer, especially Wilms tumor and carcinoid tumors. The prognosis is generally excellent, and most patients do not require special intervention.    



Option Analysis

❌ Defective tissue differentiation:
Incorrect: An example of defective tissue differentiation would be multicystic dysplastic kidney disease, which occurs due to failure of the ureteric bud to induce differentiation of the metanephric mesoderm during embryonic development. This condition results in a nonfunctional kidney consisting of cysts and connective tissue. However, this patient's imaging findings favor another diagnosis.  
❌ Failure of neural crest cell migration:
Incorrect: An example of failed neural crest cell migration would be Hirschsprung disease, a form of congenital megacolon caused by a lack of ganglion cells in the rectum. Patients typically present with constipation, abdominal distention, and explosive expulsion of feces. In contrast, this patient has no history of gastrointestinal symptoms.  
❌ Impaired tissue obliteration:
Incorrect: Failure of the vitelline duct to obliterate would cause a Meckel diverticulum. The diverticulum may contain ectopic acid-secreting gastric mucosa and/or pancreatic tissue. Patients are usually young children and may present with hematochezia, abdominal pain, and intussusception. In contrast, this patient’s imaging findings show a renal abnormality.  
✅ Fusion anomaly:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Abnormal ureteral bifurcation:
Incorrect: Bifurcation of the ureteric bud before it enters the metanephric blastema during embryonic development would result in a duplex collecting system. The condition is associated with vesicoureteral reflux, ureteral obstruction, and increased risk for UTIs. However, this patient's imaging findings favor another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 3 para 1, at 20 weeks gestation comes to the clinic for routine prenatal ultrasonography. She reports no recent changes in her health. The fetal ultrasound shows an amniotic fluid index of ≤ 5 cm (normal 8-18 cm), as well as bilateral deformities of the upper and lower extremities. Further evaluation is most likely to reveal which of the following associated conditions?
questions.solution:
This patient’s ultrasound shows a low amniotic fluid index, indicating oligohydramnios, and bilateral limb deformities, which suggests Potter sequence. Any cause of low amniotic fluid can lead to Potter sequence, including placental insufficiency, bilateral renal agenesis, and posterior urethral valves (in males).  

During the first trimester, amniotic fluid volume is derived from the maternal compartment, fetal secretions, and placenta. During the second trimester, fetal urine becomes the primary source of amniotic fluid. A urinary tract anomaly can lead to anuria/oliguria, which causes oligohydramnios.    

The lack of amniotic fluids causes the fetus to become compressed in utero. The result is Potter sequence, which is characterized by severe intrauterine growth restriction, craniofacial and limb deformities, as well as lung hypoplasia. Lung hypoplasia occurs because the fetus needs to aspirate a certain amount of amniotic fluid in order to expand and develop its lungs.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Cleft palate:
Incorrect: Cleft palate occurs when there is a lack of a connection between the roof of the mouth and the nose. It is caused by failed fusion of the two lateral palatine shelves or failed fusion of the lateral palatine shelf with the nasal septum/median palatine shelf. It is not associated with renal agenesis or oligohydramnios.  
✅ Lung hypoplasia:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Macrosomia :
Incorrect: Macrosomia is defined as a birth weight exceeding 4 kg (8.8 lb), regardless of gestational age. Macrosomia is associated with gestational diabetes, which would instead result in polyhydramnios, since the elevated maternal blood glucose leads to osmotic diuresis in the fetus.   
❌ Spina bifida occulta:
Incorrect: Spina bifida occulta is a type of neural tube defect. It is characterized by failed closure of the spinal canal but no herniation of neural tissues. Neural tube defects are often associated with low folic acid intake during pregnancy or use of certain medications (e.g. valproate). Spina bifida is not associated with oligohydramnios.  
❌ Urachal fistula:
Incorrect: A urachal fistula occurs when there is failure of the urachus to degenerate, resulting in open communication between the bladder and umbilicus. Patients may have excretion of urine via the umbilicus. The condition is not a cause of oligohydramnios.  
❌ Duodenal atresia:
Incorrect: Duodenal atresia occurs when the duodenum fails to recanalize properly. This results in the inability to swallow amniotic fluid and leads to polyhydramnios, not oligohydramnios.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male comes to the office for a follow-up appointment due to bloody urine and flank pain. He generally feels well, and medical history is unremarkable. The patient mentions that his father had high blood pressure and died at the age of 50 from cardiac complications. The patient does not use tobacco, excessive alcohol, or illicit substances. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 147/90 mmHg. A CT of the abdomen is obtained and shown below:  


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons 
This patient’s condition follows which of the following inheritance patterns?
questions.solution:
This has hypertension, hematuria, flank pain, and abdominal CT showing bilateral cystic masses. He has autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD).  

ADPKD, as the name suggests, is an autosomal dominant condition caused by mutations in PKD1 gene on chromosome 16 (85% of cases) or PKD2 gene on chromosome 4 (15% of cases). The age of presentation is variable, though most patients become symptomatic in adulthood and develop end-stage renal disease (ERSD) at age 50-70 years old. Of note, patients with PKD2 mutations usually have a less severe phenotype and develop ESRD later than patients with PKD1 mutations.  

Flank pain is the most common complaint and occurs due to renal hemorrhage, calculi, or urinary tract infection. Patients can also have hypertension, hematuria, proteinuria, and impaird kidney function. Bilateral flank masses can sometimes be palpated. ADPKD is associated with some extra-renal manifestations, including berry aneurysms, mitral valve prolapse, benign hepatic cysts, and diverticulosis.    

Interestingly, the majority of patients with ADPKD die from cardiac causes, more specifically cardiac hypertrophy and coronary artery disease. Diagnosis can be made by obtaining a detailed family history and confirming via imaging. Genetic testing is generally not required.  

Option Analysis

✅ Autosomal dominant: chromosome 16:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Autosomal recessive: chromosome 6:
Incorrect: Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) is caused by mutations in the PKHD1 gene on chromosome 6. However, patients with ARPKD typically develop symptoms in utero or immediately after birth. Also, ARPKD is associated with liver disorders such as liver fibrosis and portal hypertension, which are not seen in this patient. This patient presentation is more consistent with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, which most frequently involves chromosomes 16.   
❌ Autosomal recessive: chromosome 7  :
Incorrect: Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive condition caused by defects in the CFTR gene on chromosome 7, most commonly due to a deletion of Phe508. However, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, which most frequently involves chromosome 16.   
❌ Autosomal dominant: chromosome 3:
Incorrect: Von Hippel-Lindau disease is an autosomal dominant condition caused by a deletion of the VHL gene on chromosome 3p. It is associated with the development of tumors, ranging from the renal cell carcinoma to hemangioblastoma. However, this patient has hypertension, hematuria, and bilateral cystic masses, which is more consistent with the presentation of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease.  
❌ X-linked dominant:
Incorrect: Fragile X is an X-linked dominant condition caused by a trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene. Symptoms include cognitive impairment, long faces, and macroorchidism. In contrast, this patient has hypertension, hematuria, and bilateral cystic masses, which is more consistent with the presentation of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman is being evaluated for recurrent urinary tract infections. During the past year, she had 4 urinary tract infections, each of which required antibiotics. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable. The patient does not use tobacco, excessive alcohol, or illicit substances. She is in a monogamous relationship with her partner of 15 years. She works as a computer programmer and lives with her partner and 2 children. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. Intravenous urography is performed, and the results are shown below:  

Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons 

The doctor explains to the patient that the condition occured due to abnormal development of the embryonic kidneys. At which developmental phase did the patient's condition most likely occur?

choices.text: Development of the ureteric bud from the nephrogenic cord
Growth of the ureteric bud into the ureteric stalk
Ureteric bud lengthening and secretion of growth factors
Ureteric bud growing within the metanephric mesoderm

questions.solution:
This patient has recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs), which raises concern for an underlying condition. The intravenous urography imaging shows two ureters coming out of the left kidney, confirming the diagnosis of a duplex collecting system.   

During embryonic development, the intermediate mesoderm condenses to form a cylindrical structure called the urogenital ridge. The portion of the urogenital ridge called the nephrogenic cord eventually gives rise to the metanephros, which forms the ureteric buds. Overtime, the ureteric buds lengthen and secrete growth factors that cause the metanephric mesoderm (also termed metanephric mesenchyme) to grow in a process termed reciprocal induction. The metanephric mesoderm gives rise to the glomeruli, proximal tubules, loop of Henle, and distal convoluted tubule. The ureteric bud develops into the collecting system, minor and major calyces, renal pelvis, and ureters.  

A duplex collecting system can occur via 2 mechanisms. First, bifurcation of the ureteric bud before it enters the metanephric blastema results in a Y-shaped bifid ureter (partial duplication). Second, two ureteric buds develop and interact with the metanephric blastema, resulting in 2 seperate collecting systems, as seen here (complete duplication).  

Duplex collecting systems can be asymptomatic or present with urinary tract infections, hydronephrosis, and vesicoureteral reflux. In symptomatic patients, referral to a urologist is warranted for surgical repair.  

Option Analysis

✅ Development of the ureteric bud from the nephrogenic cord:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Growth of the ureteric bud into the ureteric stalk:
Incorrect: The growth of the ureteric bud into the urteretic stalk forms the future ureter. Duplication of the collecting system can occur at this phase if the ureteric bud were to split in two before reaching and interacting with the metanephric blastema. However, this pathway would lead to a Y-shaped bifid ureter, rather than the two separate ureters seen on imaging.  
❌ Ureteric bud lengthening and secretion of growth factors:
Incorrect: The ureteric bud lengthening and secretion of growth factors causes the metanephric blastema to grow. Eventually, the ureteric bud reaches the metanephric mesoderm and grows into it. A duplex collecting system would not be formed at this step.  
❌ Ureteric bud growing within the metanephric mesoderm:
Incorrect: As the ureteric bud grows within the metanephric mesoderm, the ureteric bud divides in half to form the renal pelvis. Each renal pelvis then divides in half to form two major calyces. A duplex collecting system would not be formed at this step.

questions.text: A 24-year-old gravida 1 para 0 woman at 27 weeks of gestation comes to the office for evaluation of a low amniotic fluid index discovered on a biophysical profile. The pregnancy has been complicated by gestational diabetes mellitus. The patient is currently on an insulin regimen. Fetal ultrasonography shows bilateral absence of the kidneys. The doctor explains to the mother that this is most likely due to aberrant interaction between the ureteric bud and metanephric mesenchyme. Which of the following structures does the ureteric bud give rise to under normal conditions?
questions.solution:
The fetus has bilateral kidney agenesis, a pathology incompatible with life. The absence of amniotic fluid causes severe pulmonary hypoplasia and respiratory insufficiency at birth. In contrast, unilateral agenesis is compatible with life, since the single kidney is able to compensate for the missing one.  

During embryonic development, the intermediate mesoderm condenses to form a cylindrical structure called the urogenital ridge. The portion of the urogenital ridge called the nephrogenic cord eventually gives rise to the metanephros, which forms the ureteric buds. Overtime, the ureteric buds lengthen and secrete growth factors that cause the metanephric mesoderm (also termed metanephric mesenchyme) to grow in a process termed reciprocal induction. The metanephric mesoderm gives rise to the glomeruli, proximal tubules, loop of Henle, and distal convoluted tubule. The ureteric bud develops into the collecting system, minor and major calyces, renal pelvis, and ureters.  

If the ureteric buds fail to develop, renal agenesis occurs. In contrast, if the ureteric buds develop but fail to induce differentiation of the metanephric mesoderm, then multicystic dysplastic kidney disease occurs.    





Option Analysis

❌ Glomeruli :
Incorrect: The glomeruli arise from the metanephric mesoderm. Please see the “Main Explanation” for additional information.   
❌ Proximal convoluted tubule:
Incorrect: The proximal convoluted tubule is derived from the metanephric mesoderm. Please see the “Main Explanation” for additional information.   
❌ Loop of Henle :
Incorrect: The Loop of Henle is derived from the metanephric mesoderm. Please see the “Main Explanation” for additional information.   
❌ Distal convoluted tubule:
Incorrect: The distal convoluted tubule is derived from the metanephric mesoderm. Please see the “Main Explanation” for additional information.   
✅ Collecting system:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida woman at 24 weeks of gestation comes to the office for a routine prenatal evaluation. The pregnancy has been uncomplicated, and she has been compliant with prenatal care. She takes vitamins as needed. Family and medical history are unremarkable. She did not have prior abortions or miscarriages. During ultrasound examination of the fetus, male external genitalia are visible, as well as bilateral hydronephrosis. An amniotic fluid index is equivocal. Which of the following is most likely the cause for the abnormal findings?

choices.text: Failure of urethral folds to fuse
Abnormal positioning of the genital tubercle
Incomplete fusion of the labioscrotal folds
Failure of the urachus to obliterate

questions.solution:
This primigravida fetus has bilateral hydronephrosis, which raises suspicion for a urinary tract anomaly. Posterior urethral valves are the most common etiology of urinary tract obstruction in newborn males.     Posterior urethral valve (PUV) is a congenital disorder in males wherein the posterior urethra, which is the section of the urethra nearest the bladder, is obstructed by membranous folds of tissue. The exact pathogenesis is unclear, but the following mechanisms have been proposed:    

  •  Patency of the urogenital membrane with abnormal canalization of the urethra. 
  •  Overgrowth of urethrovesicular folds. 
  •  Abnormal union of the Wolffian duct into the posterior urethra. 
Prenatal ultrasonographic findings suggestive of PUV include bilateral hydronephrosis, dilated bladder, bladder wall thickening, and a dilated posterior urethra (keyhole sign). In severe cases of obstruction, oligohydramnios may develop. Postnatally, infants may present with respiratory distress due to lung hypoplasia from low amounts of amniotic fluid. Other signs and symptoms include abdominal distension, difficulty voiding, a poor urinary stream, and urinary tract infections. The condition is frequently accompanied by vesicoureteral reflux, secondary to increased intravesical pressure.    Prenatally, diagnosis can be made with ultrasound. Postnatally, diagnosis can be made by a voiding cystourethrogram demonstrating a dilated and elongated posterior urethra with a thin linear defect during the voiding phase. Definitive treatment involves surgical ablation of the membrane.      



Option Analysis

❌ Failure of urethral folds to fuse:
Incorrect: Failure of the urethral folds to fuse would cause hypospadias, an abnormal opening of the penile urethra on the ventral surface of penis. It is typically diagnosed at birth and is associated with cryptorchidism. It would not cause bilateral hydronephrosis.   
❌ Abnormal positioning of the genital tubercle:
Incorrect: Abnormal positioning of the genital tubercle can cause epispadias, an abnormal opening of the penile urethra on the dorsal surface of penis. It is associated with bladder exstrophy, which would be seen on ultrasound. However, the condition would not cause bilateral hydronephrosis.   
✅ Persistence of the urogenital membrane :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Incomplete fusion of the labioscrotal folds:
Incorrect: Incomplete fusion of the labioscrotal folds is the cause of bifid scrotum, which presents as a deep midline cleft in the scrotum. However, bifid scrotum is not associated with bilateral hydronephrosis.   
❌ Failure of the urachus to obliterate:
Incorrect: Failure of the urachus to obliterate would result in a patent urachus, which would allow urine to travel from the bladder to the umbilicus. The condition would cause urine to be discharged from the umbilicus and is usually identified at birth. It would not, however, cause bilateral hydronephrosis.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, at 26 weeks gestation is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding following a motor vehicle accident three hours ago. A stat transvaginal ultrasound reveals placental abruption. After adequate resuscitation, the patient is brought to the operating room for emergent c-section. Approximate blood loss is 2500 mL. Several hours following the surgery, she endorses sudden onset bilateral flank pain. Physical examination shows bilateral costovertebral angle tenderness. Urine output in the last 6 hours is measured at 30mL. Laboratory results are shown.

 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin  8.5 g/dL 
 Leukocytes  10,000 /mL 
 Platelets  330,000/mm3 
 Serum chemistry 
 Sodium  136 mEq/L 
 Potassium  5.8 mEq/L 
 Chloride  85 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  19 mEq/L 
 Creatinine  1.7 mg/dL 
 Blood urea nitrogen (BUN)  40 mg/dL 
 Urinalysis 
 Erythrocytes  30-32/hpf 
 Leukocyte esterase  Negative 
 Leukocytes  2/hpf 
 Protein  1.0 g/day 
 Urine osmolality  650 mOsm/kg 
 Dysmorphic red blood cells  Absent 
 Cast  Tubular cell casts 
   
A renal ultrasound demonstrates hypoechoic areas in the renal cortex. Which of the following pathologic processes is responsible for this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
The findings of placental abruption, bilateral flank pain, rising creatinine and ultrasound findings of hypoechogenic areas in the renal cortex are consistent with renal cortical necrosis, a type of prerenal acute kidney injury.  

Renal cortical necrosis results from decreased perfusion to the renal cortical end-arteries secondary to thrombosis or vasospasm. Reduced blood supply induces tissue ischemia and inflammation of the cortex. It also results in vasoconstriction of afferent arterioles, with a subsequent decrease in glomerular filtration rate, and ultimately decreased urine output. Parts of the proximal convoluted tubule and thick ascending loop of Henle in the cortex are most commonly affected due to high metabolic activity in this anatomic region.  

Renal cortical necrosis has been associated with obstetric complications, including placenta abruption, prolonged intrauterine fetal death, infected abortion, and eclampsia. The stretching and swelling of the renal capsule causes flank pain and costovertebral angle tenderness. Laboratory evaluation typically shows azotemia, increased creatinine, hematuria, and increased urinary osmolality. Diagnosis requires evidence of cortical ischemia and necrosis on imaging (ultrasound or CT scan). Biopsy of the affected kidney shows patchy necrosis and atrophy of renal cortex.

Option Analysis

❌ Bacterial infiltration of renal parenchyma:
Incorrect: Bacterial infiltration of renal parenchyma is the underlying etiology of pyelonephritis. These patients present with fever, chills, dysuria, and flank pain. Urinalysis typically reveals elevated leukocytes and positive leukocyte esterase.  
✅ Ischemic necrosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Glomerular inflammation:
Incorrect: Glomerular inflammation induces glomerular basement membrane damage with subsequent  hematuria and proteinuria. Urinalysis reveals red blood cell casts and dysmorphic red blood cells. 
❌ Renal interstitial inflammation:
Incorrect: Renal interstitial inflammation, also known as acute interstitial nephritis, is commonly induced by antibiotics or autoimmune disease. Though hematuria can be seen, it is usually associated with fever, rash, pyuria, and costovertebral angle tenderness.  
❌ Urinary obstruction:
Incorrect: Urinary obstruction results from blockage of ureters by a gravid uterus or iatrogenic injury to the ureters during cesarean section. Though it can present with oliguria, ultrasound shows hydronephrosis of the affected side, rather than hypoechogenic areas of renal cortex.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of intractable vomiting for the past 24 hours. Last night she ate a hamburger from a local restaurant, and since then she has had multiple episodes of bilious emesis. Past medical history is significant for osteoarthritis and hypertension. Current medications include ibuprofen and lisinopril. Her temperature is 36.6°C (97.8° F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 101/62 mm Hg. Physical examination demonstrates decreased skin turgor and dry oral mucosa. A liver function assay is within normal limits. The remainder of the laboratory studies are shown below.  

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin  13 g/dL 
 Leukocytes  10,000 /mL 
 Platelets  330,000/mm3 
 Serum chemistry 
 Sodium  136 mEq/L 
 Potassium  2.8 mEq/L 
 Chloride  85 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  29 mEq/L 
 Creatinine  1.7 mg/dL 
 Blood urea nitrogen (BUN)  40 mg/dL 
 Urinalysis 
 Erythrocytes  1-2/hpf 
 Leukocytes  1-2/hpf 
 Fractional excretion of sodium (FENa)  <1% 
 Urine osmolality  650 mOsm/kg 
 Sediment  None 
   
Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of tachycardia, hypotension, and volume depletion due to intractable vomiting, together with the BUN:Cr >20, is strongly suggestive of prerenal acute kidney injury (AKI). Acute kidney injury refers to an abrupt decline in renal function, resulting in a decrease in glomerular filtration rate, and subsequent accumulation of nitrogenous waste products.  

AKI is divided into three categories dependent on the site of injury: prerenal AKI (e.g., bleeding, volume depletion, sepsis), intrarenal AKI (e.g., acute tubular necrosis, glomerulonephritis, or interstitial nephritis) or post-renal AKI (e.g., BPH, stones, malignancy). The etiology of renal injury can be determined via clinical history as well as via assessment of urine osmolality, urine sodium, FENa, and the serum BUN/Cr.
 
 Patients with prerenal AKI have reduced renal perfusion, and in an attempt to conserve the glomerular filtration rate (GFR), the kidney reabsorbs more sodium (leading to a FeNa<1%) and urea. Creatinine, however, is not reabsorbed, and thus the BUN/Cr ratio is >20. Since the kidney absorbs water to maintain GFR, the urine becomes highly concentrated, with osmolality >500 mOsm/kg. Irrespective of etiology, untreated AKI can lead to several complications including anemia, pericarditis and encephalopathy. 

Option Analysis

❌ Hemolytic uremic syndrome:
Incorrect: Hemolytic uremic syndrome occurs in response to shiga-like toxin-producing organisms and presents with a triad of acute kidney injury, hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia 1-2 weeks following a diarrheal illness. Although this patient’s serum chemistry is indicative of acute kidney injury, there is no evidence of anemia or thrombocytopenia.  
✅ Prerenal azotemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Hepatorenal syndrome:
Incorrect: Hepatorenal syndrome refers to acute kidney injury secondary to portal hypertension and  chronic liver disease. Although this patient’s serum chemistry is indicative of acute kidney injury, a normal liver function assay makes this diagnosis unlikely. 
❌ Renal papillary necrosis:
Incorrect: Although renal papillary necrosis can occur in the setting of chronic analgesic use, urinalysis usually demonstrates hematuria and proteinuria. Moreover, this patient’s increased BUN:Cr (>20) in the setting of volume depletion, suggests a prerenal (not intrarenal) cause of acute kidney injury. 
❌ Acute interstitial nephritis:
Incorrect: Acute interstitial nephritis refers to acute inflammation of the renal interstitium. It is commonly induced by drugs (mainly antibiotics) or autoimmune disease, and it presents with fever, rash, pyuria, hematuria and costovertebral angle tenderness.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man presents to the emergency department with difficulty breathing over the past two days. His past medical history is significant for chronic liver disease secondary to chronic alcohol use disorder. His temperature is 36.6°C (97.8° F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows abdominal distention with shifting dullness. Serum creatinine concentration is 1.5 mg/dL, and serum urea nitrogen concentration is 20 mg/dL. The patient is started on furosemide, and his condition quickly improves. Three days later, repeated laboratory studies show the following:

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum 
 Sodium  132 mEq/L 
 Potassium  4.2 mEq/L 
 Chloride  95 mEq/L 
 Creatinine  1.9 mg/dL 
 Albumin  3.2 g/dL 
 BUN/Cr  > 20 
 Urine 
 Erythrocytes  0/hpf 
 Leukocytes  2/hpf 
 Fractional excretion of sodium (FENa)  <1% 
 Urine osmolality  600 mOsm/kg 
 Sediment  None 
 
 Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with difficulty breathing most likely due to volume overload secondary to ascites from decompensated chronic liver disease. This diagnosis is supported by the fact that treatment with furosemide improves his condition. However, laboratory results a few days later show a rising creatinine, a low fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) <1% and a high urine osmolality of 600 mOsm/kg, which is consistent with prerenal acute kidney injury (AKI) from volume depletion from the furosemide therapy.      

AKI can be divided into categories based on where the problem has occurred: prerenal AKI (e.g., bleeding, volume depletion, sepsis), intrarenal AKI (e.g., acute tubular necrosis, glomerulonephritis, or interstitial nephritis) or post-renal AKI (e.g., BPH, stones, malignancy). To establish the cause of renal injury, it is essential to assess the urine osmolality, urine sodium, FENa, and the serum BUN/Cr.    

In prerenal AKI, the kidney detects reduced blood flow. In an attempt to conserve the glomerular filtration rate (GFR), the kidney reabsorbs more sodium (leading to a FeNa<1%) and urea. Creatinine, however, is not reabsorbed, and thus BUN/Cr ratio is >20. Because the kidney is absorbing fluids to maintain GFR, the urine is highly concentrated and usually >500 mOsm/kg.


Option Analysis

❌ Acute tubular necrosis:
Incorrect: Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) is a cause of intrarenal acute kidney injury due to ischemic (e.g., hypotension, shock) or cytotoxic causes (e.g., aminoglycosides, radiocontrast agents, lead, cisplatin). In ATN, the urine osmolality is usually <350 (mOsm/kg) and the FENa> 2%. Granular muddy brown casts are also seen in the urine. 
❌ Diabetic nephropathy:
Incorrect: Diabetic nephropathy is a progressive chronic condition that causes a gradual decline in renal function. This patient's drastic change in renal function favors another diagnosis. Additionally, this patient laboratory findings suggest prerenal acute kidney injury. 
❌ Syndrome of increased antidiuretic hormone (SIADH):
Incorrect: SIADH can be caused by certain medications (e.g., cyclophosphamide, SSRI). This patient is not taking any of these nephrotoxic medications, and the laboratory findings favor a different diagnosis. Additionally, SIADH would lead to euvolemic hyponatremia, not hypervolemia and ascites as seen in this patient.   
❌ Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus:
Incorrect: Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus can be hereditary (ADH receptor mutation) or secondary to hypercalcemia, hypokalemia, lithium use, or demeclocycline use. In nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, urine osmolality is expected to be <300 mOsm/kg. 
❌ Renal artery stenosis:
Incorrect: Renal artery stenosis is a possible cause of prerenal acute kidney injury. However, patients usually have a history of hypertension resistant to medical treatment. Another possible manifestation is at least 30% rise in serum creatinine following ACEI or ARB use. This patient received furosemide, and the serum creatinine increased by less than 30%. 
✅ Volume depletion:
Correct: See Main Explanation

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of lower abdominal discomfort for an hour. He has not urinated since yesterday and has had difficulty initiating urination for the past three months. He has not had weight loss, dysuria, urgency, or dribbling of urine. The patient had a viral illness two days ago for which he started taking acetaminophen for fever. Current vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a palpable mass in the suprapubic area. A symmetric, enlarged non-tender prostate is palpated on digital rectal examination. Glomerular filtration rate is 40 ml/min/1.73m2. Urinalysis is shown.  

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum chemistry 
 Blood urea nitrogen  36 mg/dL 
 Creatinine  1.9 mg/dL 
 Urinalysis 
 Proteinuria  Absent 
 Dysmorphic red blood cells  Absent 
 Sodium (UNa)  15 mEq/L 
 Fractional excretion of sodium (FENa)  <1% 
 Urine osmolality  650 mOsm/kg 
 Sediment  None 
   
If left untreated, which of the following laboratory findings are most likely to be observed in the coming weeks?

choices.text: Red blood cell casts on urinalysis

questions.solution:
This patient’s history of poor urine flow and difficulty initiating urination, together with examination findings of a symmetric, enlarged non-tender prostate, are consistent with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). His abdominal discomfort and palpable mass in the suprapubic area points towards acute urinary retention due to bladder outlet obstruction, resulting in postrenal acute kidney injury (AKI).  

Postrenal AKI occurs due to a buildup of pressure from an obstruction to the outflow of the kidneys. Besides prostate enlargement, this condition may occur due to bilateral obstructing calculi or mass effect from surrounding tumors. The increased pressure in renal tubules lowers the glomerular pressure gradient, decreasing the glomerular filtration rate (GFR), resulting in increased creatinine levels, azotemia and oliguria. An increase in tubular pressure facilitates the reabsorption of sodium, water and urea--decreasing the urinary sodium to <20 mEq/L and FENa to <1% and increasing the urinary osmolality to >500 mOsm/kg and BUN:Cr to >15.  

If postrenal AKI is left untreated, the increased pressure may further lower the GFR and damage the tubular cells responsible for reabsorption. The latter results in a fall of urinary osmolality to <350 mOsm/kg and of BUN:Cr to <15. Moreover, it increases sodium excretion, causing urinary sodium >40 mEq/L and FENa >1%.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Urine sodium >40 mEq/L:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Urine osmolality >750 mOsm/kg:
Incorrect: If postrenal azotemia is left untreated, pressure builds and damages the renal tubules and epithelial cells responsible for reabsorption of water, causing the urine to be less concentrated. This damage results in the fall in urine osmolality to below 350 mOsm/kg. 
❌ Red blood cell casts on urinalysis:
Incorrect: Red blood cell casts are seen in nephritic syndrome, which presents with hematuria, edema and hypertension. Lab findings demonstrate proteinuria, dysmorphic red blood cells, and red blood cell casts. 
❌ Glomerular filtration rate of 70 ml/min/1.73m2:
Incorrect: The rise in renal tubular pressure due to postrenal obstruction reduces the pressure gradient across the glomeruli, resulting in decreased (not increased) glomerular filtration rate. 
❌ Serum creatinine levels of 1.2 mg/dL:
Incorrect: Normally, kidneys excrete most of the creatinine with little to no reabsorption. If postrenal azotemia is left untreated, serum creatinine is expected to rise (not fall), since glomerular filtration is decreased.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man comes to his primary care physician’s office for routine follow-up. He was recently diagnosed with osteoarthritis of the knees four weeks ago and was initiated on analgesic medications. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin, naproxen and acetaminophen. His vitals and physical exam are within normal limits. Laboratory results are as follows.  

 Laboratory value  Results 
  4 weeks ago  Today 
 Serum chemistry 
 Sodium  138 mEq/L  137 mEq/L 
 Potassium  4 mEq/L  4.1 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  24 mEq/L  25 mEq/L 
 Chloride  96 mEq/L  94 mEq/L 
 Creatinine  1.1 mg/dL  1.6 mg/dL 
 Urinalysis 
 Protein  100 mg/day  102 mg/day 
 Cast  None  None 
 Blood  negative  negative 
   
Changes to which of the following anatomic regions is most likely accountable for this patient’s rise in creatinine?
questions.solution:
This patient was recently started on a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) for osteoarthritis. His renal profile after one month of use demonstrates a rise in serum creatinine, reflecting the effects of NSAIDs on the afferent arteriole.   

Prostaglandins are produced by lipids under the action of phospholipase A2 and cyclooxygenase enzymes, and they act to dilate renal afferent arterioles. NSAIDs prevent the production of prostaglandins via inhibition of cyclooxygenase, thereby inducing constriction of the afferent arterioles and decreased blood flow to nephrons. NSAID-induced kidney injury is often exacerbated by concomitant chronic kidney disease and volume depletion (aggressive diuresis, nephrotic syndrome, heart failure, diarrhea and vomiting).


Conversely, angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEIs) prevent efferent arteriolar constriction by inhibiting the production of angiotensin II, which normally vasoconstricts efferent arterioles to maintain the glomerular filtration rate. A slight rise in serum creatinine concentration can be observed in healthy patients within the first two weeks, but a >30% elevation may occur in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis, hypertensive nephrosclerosis, polycystic kidney disease, or chronic kidney disease. 

Option Analysis

✅ Afferent arterioles:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Efferent arterioles:
Incorrect: Efferent arterioles are affected by angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors. They prevent efferent arteriolar vasoconstriction via inhibition of the formation of angiotensin II, resulting in decreased glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Although reduction in GFR may cause a slight increase in serum creatinine, this patient is not using this medication. 
❌ Distal convoluted tubule:
Incorrect: Thiazide diuretics inhibit the reabsorption of sodium and chloride in the distal convoluted tubule, while decreasing calcium and urea reabsorption. However, they do not usually affect serum creatinine levels. 
❌ Ascending loop of Henle:
Incorrect: Loop diuretics inhibit the Na/K/2Cl transporter of the thick ascending limb loop of Henle. Loop diuretic use is associated with an increase in vasodilatory effects of prostaglandins on afferent arterioles without affecting serum creatinine levels. 
❌ Collecting duct:
Incorrect: Competitive aldosterone receptor blockers like spironolactone act at the cortical collecting tubule cells. This medication can lead to hyperkalemia, but it does not typically affect serum creatinine concentration.
